title: Chinese Government dispatches medical experts to Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital (Linked to Project ID#32020)
description: On May 8, 2007, the Ministry of National Defense of China dispatched four Chinese medical experts, Sihaichen, Nie Yongkang, Zhang Wuxing and Liu Gang, to the Preah Ket Melea military hospital in Phnom Penh to improve its medical level. It is part of a RMB 30 million pledge to Cambodia for the renovation and donation to the hospital and the construction of a Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution. (see project #32020)  On January 14, 2008, the completion ceremony was held and the head of the General Administration of Logistics and Finance of the Ministry of National Defense of Cambodia, General Song Sangnan, awarded the "Friendship and Cooperation Medal" approved by the Prime Minister of the Royal Government of Cambodia to the four Chinese military doctors in the Hospital of Cambodia for their past 9 months of contribution to improving the medical technology of the hospital. ("柬埔寨国防部向中国援柬军医授勋").
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches medical experts to Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital (Linked to Project ID#32020)

# Description
On May 8, 2007, the Ministry of National Defense of China dispatched four Chinese medical experts, Sihaichen, Nie Yongkang, Zhang Wuxing and Liu Gang, to the Preah Ket Melea military hospital in Phnom Penh to improve its medical level. It is part of a RMB 30 million pledge to Cambodia for the renovation and donation to the hospital and the construction of a Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution. (see project #32020)  On January 14, 2008, the completion ceremony was held and the head of the General Administration of Logistics and Finance of the Ministry of National Defense of Cambodia, General Song Sangnan, awarded the "Friendship and Cooperation Medal" approved by the Prime Minister of the Royal Government of Cambodia to the four Chinese military doctors in the Hospital of Cambodia for their past 9 months of contribution to improving the medical technology of the hospital. ("柬埔寨国防部向中国援柬军医授勋").
justification: Project focuses on healthcare capacity building and medical expertise transfer, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Dispatch of medical experts, hospital renovation, medical technology improvement focus

title: Chinese Ministry of Defense donates military band and medical equipment to Cambodia
description: On December 6, 2007, the Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China donated military band equipment to the Royal Army of Cambodia and medical equipment to the Preah Ket Mealea Hospital in Cambodia (or 向柬埔寨王家军提供军乐团装备与医疗设备). The handover ceremony was held at the Preah Ket Mealea military hospital. Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia Zhang Jinfeng and State Secretary of the Ministry of National Defense of Cambodia, General Monsoppan, attended the handover ceremony. The aid materials provided by the Chinese side include musical instruments and transportation for the military band, hemodialysis machines, water treatment machines, and some office equipment.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Defense donates military band and medical equipment to Cambodia

# Description
On December 6, 2007, the Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China donated military band equipment to the Royal Army of Cambodia and medical equipment to the Preah Ket Mealea Hospital in Cambodia (or 向柬埔寨王家军提供军乐团装备与医疗设备). The handover ceremony was held at the Preah Ket Mealea military hospital. Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia Zhang Jinfeng and State Secretary of the Ministry of National Defense of Cambodia, General Monsoppan, attended the handover ceremony. The aid materials provided by the Chinese side include musical instruments and transportation for the military band, hemodialysis machines, water treatment machines, and some office equipment.
justification: Project involves donation of medical and musical equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Military band equipment, medical equipment (hemodialysis machines, water treatment machines), office equipment

title: Chinese Embassy in Cameroon donates computers and laser-printers to CRTV
description: On December 11, 2007, the Chinese embassy in Cameroon gifted ten high-definition computers with flat screens and five laser-printers to the Cameroon Radio Television Corporation (CRTV) at the CRTV production center in Mballa II. The donation was promised during the Chinese ambassador, Wang Changqin's, first visit to CRTV. The gifts were handed over by Wang Changqin during this second visit and were received by CTRV's director general, Amadou Vamoulke.
combined_text:
# Sector

The gifts were handed over by Wang Changqin during this second visit and were received by CTRV's director general, Amadou Vamoulke.
justification: Project involves donation of computer equipment to support media operations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of computers and printers to Cameroon Radio Television Corporation for media production purposes

title: Chinese Government provides a grant for the construction of two primary schools in Nanga Eboko and Guider
description: On January 31, 2007, the Chinese Government signed an agreement to donate tow schools to Cameroon. The construction project was completed by Shenyang International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd. and Chongqing International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd. Chongqing International Construction Copperation (CICO) began construction on September 15th, 2008, and passed the internal examination on March 23, 2009. China Shenyang International Economic & Technical Cooperation Co,. Ltd. (CSYIC) began construction on Septermber 30th, 2008, and passed the internal examination on February 5th, 2009. The handover contract was signed on December 31st by Chinese Ambassador Huang Changqing and Cameroon Minister of Education YOUSSOUF Née HADIDJA ALIM. Construction on the schools ended by July 2009.
combined_text:

Chongqing International Construction Copperation (CICO) began construction on September 15th, 2008, and passed the internal examination on March 23, 2009. China Shenyang International Economic & Technical Cooperation Co,. Ltd. (CSYIC) began construction on Septermber 30th, 2008, and passed the internal examination on February 5th, 2009. The handover contract was signed on December 31st by Chinese Ambassador Huang Changqing and Cameroon Minister of Education YOUSSOUF Née HADIDJA ALIM. Construction on the schools ended by July 2009.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of two primary schools, education sector focus

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 350 million government concessional loan for Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project (Linked to Project ID#31230 and ID#91746)
description: On January 31, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cameroon signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project . On the same day, China Eximbank and the Government of the Republic of Cameroon signed an RMB 350 million (CFA 29 billion) government concessional loan (GCL) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. 5 (2007) TOTAL NO. (176)] for the Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a maturity of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate of 2%, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 0.3% commitment fee, and a 0.3% management fee.   The proceeds of the loan were on-lent by the Government of the Republic of Cameroon to CAMTEL (a state-owned telecommunications and Internet service provider in Cameroon). CAMTEL, as the ‘end-user’ and ultimate borrower, was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance a commercial contract (ID# 2006/025/GG/DG/CPM-AG/CAMTEL) between CAMTEL and from Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd., which was signed on April 11, 2006. As of December 31, 2020, the CFA 29 billion loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate and its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 13.2 billion. Its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 20 billion as of December 31, 2016, CFA 17 billion as of December 31, 2017, CFA 15 billion as of December 31, 2018, and CFA 14 billion as of December 31, 2019.   The purpose of the project was to enable CAMTEL’s acquisition of wireless (CDMA) phone technology and facilitate the installation of 350,000 CDMA lines. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd.  was the contractor responsible for implementation. Several sources that this project reached implementation, but it precise implementation start and end dates are unknown. Following trials with 10,000 lines in Yaounde and Douala in 2004, CAMTEL launched a Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA)-based wireless network in September 2005, under the brand name CTPhone, to complement its fixed-line network. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd. supplied 20,000 lines in a first phase, which was later expanded to cover some other towns in the south and west of the country. Uptake was reportedly good, with around 28,000 customers signing up within the first year of operation (representing 20% of CAMTEL’s total fixed subscriber base).  There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In January 2019, Cameroon unilaterally withheld debt service payments to China Eximbank. The lender responded by withholding new loan disbursements. Then, in July 2019, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed a debt rescheduling agreement (as captured via Project ID#88213). Under the terms of the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to reschedule 18 loans previously contracted by the Government of Cameroon — with scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 — by allowing the borrower to defer scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 to later dates but without any maturity extensions. The total amount of restructured debt was equivalent CFA 148 billion ($253 million) — or 70% of the loan principal that was scheduled for repayment between July 2019 and March 2022. Under the terms of the agreement, the Government of Cameroon agreed to repay 30% of the loan principal according to the original July 2019-March 2022 schedule (i.e. without any payment deferrals). The lender and the borrower also agreed to cancel the committed but undisbursed loan balances worth approximately CFA 10 billion (for certain loans with disbursement deadlines that had already passed). Then, in January 2020, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) classified the Government Cameroon as facing a high risk of debt distress. Eighteen months later, during an address before Cameroon’s National Assembly on June 28, 2021, the Minister of Water and Energy (MINEE) Gaston Eloundou Esommba provided an update on the ICBC-financed Bini à Warak Hydroelectric Power Plant Project. He noted that the project had been 'on hold' since November 2019 because ICBC suspended the loan agreement, even though the Government of Cameroon had already mobilized XAF 22 billion of counterpart funding. He also explained that 'the reason for this suspension is that Cameroon did not settle some of its debts towards China on time, so, it is in a cross-default situation.’
staff_comments: 1. The China Eximbank loan agreement can be accessed in its entirety via SourceID#68601 or https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20485114-cmr_2007_175. 2. The French project title is Projet Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA). 3. The project identification number for this transaction in Cameroon's Development Assistance Database (DAD) is CAM/000766. 4. The April 11, 2006 commercial contract is known as the Supply, Installation and Commission of Additional 300,000 CDMA Lines Contract. 5. China Eximbank issued several additional loans to CAMTEL in 2010 and 2012 (as captured via Project ID#31230 and Project ID#91746). One official source (https://www.dropbox.com/s/a400557jut579m5/Government%20of%20Cameroon%202020%20Register%20of%20Chinese%20Loans%20and%20Borrowing%20Terms.pdf?dl=0) identifies the face value of the loan as RMB 319,285,500 and the loan commitment date as March 21, 2008. 6. The loan identification number in the Government of Cameroon's Commonwealth Secretariat Debt Recording and Management System (CS-DRMS) is 2007100.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 350 million government concessional loan for Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project (Linked to Project ID#31230 and ID#91746)

# Description
On January 31, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cameroon signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project . On the same day, China Eximbank and the Government of the Republic of Cameroon signed an RMB 350 million (CFA 29 billion) government concessional loan (GCL) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. 5 (2007) TOTAL NO. (176)] for the Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a maturity of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate of 2%, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 0.3% commitment fee, and a 0.3% management fee.   The proceeds of the loan were on-lent by the Government of the Republic of Cameroon to CAMTEL (a state-owned telecommunications and Internet service provider in Cameroon). CAMTEL, as the ‘end-user’ and ultimate borrower, was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance a commercial contract (ID# 2006/025/GG/DG/CPM-AG/CAMTEL) between CAMTEL and from Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd., which was signed on April 11, 2006. As of December 31, 2020, the CFA 29 billion loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate and its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 13.2 billion. Its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 20 billion as of December 31, 2016, CFA 17 billion as of December 31, 2017, CFA 15 billion as of December 31, 2018, and CFA 14 billion as of December 31, 2019.   The purpose of the project was to enable CAMTEL’s acquisition of wireless (CDMA) phone technology and facilitate the installation of 350,000 CDMA lines. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd.  was the contractor responsible for implementation. Several sources that this project reached implementation, but it precise implementation start and end dates are unknown. Following trials with 10,000 lines in Yaounde and Douala in 2004, CAMTEL launched a Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA)-based wireless network in September 2005, under the brand name CTPhone, to complement its fixed-line network. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd. supplied 20,000 lines in a first phase, which was later expanded to cover some other towns in the south and west of the country. Uptake was reportedly good, with around 28,000 customers signing up within the first year of operation (representing 20% of CAMTEL’s total fixed subscriber base).  There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Cameroon Telecommunications CDMA Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In January 2019, Cameroon unilaterally withheld debt service payments to China Eximbank. The lender responded by withholding new loan disbursements. Then, in July 2019, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed a debt rescheduling agreement (as captured via Project ID#88213). Under the terms of the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to reschedule 18 loans previously contracted by the Government of Cameroon — with scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 — by allowing the borrower to defer scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 to later dates but without any maturity extensions. The total amount of restructured debt was equivalent CFA 148 billion ($253 million) — or 70% of the loan principal that was scheduled for repayment between July 2019 and March 2022. Under the terms of the agreement, the Government of Cameroon agreed to repay 30% of the loan principal according to the original July 2019-March 2022 schedule (i.e. without any payment deferrals). The lender and the borrower also agreed to cancel the committed but undisbursed loan balances worth approximately CFA 10 billion (for certain loans with disbursement deadlines that had already passed). Then, in January 2020, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) classified the Government Cameroon as facing a high risk of debt distress. Eighteen months later, during an address before Cameroon’s National Assembly on June 28, 2021, the Minister of Water and Energy (MINEE) Gaston Eloundou Esommba provided an update on the ICBC-financed Bini à Warak Hydroelectric Power Plant Project. He noted that the project had been 'on hold' since November 2019 because ICBC suspended the loan agreement, even though the Government of Cameroon had already mobilized XAF 22 billion of counterpart funding. He also explained that 'the reason for this suspension is that Cameroon did not settle some of its debts towards China on time, so, it is in a cross-default situation.’
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Installation of 350,000 CDMA lines, wireless phone technology, telecommunications sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides loan for National Sports School Construction Project (linked to #22824)
description: In 2007, the Chinese Government pledged funds to construct a National Sports School in Olembe. The face value and terms of the loan are unknown; however, the total estimated cost of the project was 60 million euros.  This was part of a larger 209 million Euro renovation of Provincial Stadiums in Cameroon by the Chinese Government (see linked ProjectID#22824).  The project involved the construction of a 35,000 seat capacity National Sports School over 10 thousand square metres of land with a medical rehabilitation centre for students to recover from physical activities. The project also involved the construction of an indoor gymnasium and an aquatic centre.  China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  The project was initiated on August 6, 2004 and completed on March 11, 2009.
staff_comments: The Chinese name of this project is 喀麦隆多功能体育馆落.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides loan for National Sports School Construction Project (linked to #22824)

# Description
In 2007, the Chinese Government pledged funds to construct a National Sports School in Olembe. The face value and terms of the loan are unknown; however, the total estimated cost of the project was 60 million euros.  This was part of a larger 209 million Euro renovation of Provincial Stadiums in Cameroon by the Chinese Government (see linked ProjectID#22824).  The project involved the construction of a 35,000 seat capacity National Sports School over 10 thousand square metres of land with a medical rehabilitation centre for students to recover from physical activities. The project also involved the construction of an indoor gymnasium and an aquatic centre.  China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  The project was initiated on August 6, 2004 and completed on March 11, 2009.
justification: Project focuses on education and sports infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of National Sports School with medical rehabilitation centre, indoor gymnasium, and aquatic centre

title: China donates $3 million aid for Yaounde hospital accommodation construction in Cameroon
description: In 2007, China donated the construction of personnel accommodation at Yaounde's Hospital of Gynecology, Obstetrics, and Pediatrics worth $3 million.

title: Confucius Institute at the University of Yaoundé II
description: A Chinese Confucius Center was founded in Cameroon in November 2007. The Chinese sponsors of the project are Zhejiang Normal University (ZNU) and the University of Yaounde II. The center was founded at the International Relationships Institute of Cameroon (Institut des Relations Internationales du Cameroun, IRIC). In 2007, the Chinese Language Training Center was upgraded to the Confucius Institute with 7 teaching centers. As of 2011, the Institute had 6,000 registered students. The Yaoundé CI is based on a cooperation initiated in 1996 between the IRIC and Zhejiang Normal University, located in Jinhua.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Confucius Institute at the University of Yaoundé II

# Description
A Chinese Confucius Center was founded in Cameroon in November 2007. The Chinese sponsors of the project are Zhejiang Normal University (ZNU) and the University of Yaounde II. The center was founded at the International Relationships Institute of Cameroon (Institut des Relations Internationales du Cameroun, IRIC). In 2007, the Chinese Language Training Center was upgraded to the Confucius Institute with 7 teaching centers. As of 2011, the Institute had 6,000 registered students. The Yaoundé CI is based on a cooperation initiated in 1996 between the IRIC and Zhejiang Normal University, located in Jinhua.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Confucius Institute, Chinese Language Training Center, education-focused collaboration

title: Chinese Government equipment to the Gynaeco-Obstetrics and Paediatric Hospital of Yaounde worth FCFA 64,000,000
description: Between January 30-February 1, 2007, at a ceremony attended by Chinese President Hu Jintao and Cameroonian President Paul Biya, the Chinese Government donated equipment to the Gynaeco-Obstetrics and Paediatric Hospital of Yaounde worth FCFA 64,000,000.
